text: My first huarache was a definite success. Think Mexican flatbread, with a fresh masa crust and salsa as the sauce. Yes, it's delicious. After consulting the internet, I opted for tinga (spicy chicken, which was absolutely divine) and nopales (cactus - trust me, it's delicious). Both were fantastic - flavorful and a great contrast with the crispiness of the crust. One huarache will feed even the hungriest person, and could easily be split as an entree for lighter eaters. I saw some quesadillas and other entrees come out, all looked delicious. A bonus if you come for lunch: they have an adorable sidewalk patio with a view of the park next door!

Wow. This is another little Mexican gem in Chicago. We stumbled upon this place some months ago after we moved to Andersonville and it is our go-to place when we want some quick Mexico City-style street food. Tacos, huaraches and sopes. Nothing fancy, but very savory and very well prepared. The secret is in the salsas. The food is great, but soak your huarache in green or red salsa (or both!) and you've got yourself a winner! Small hole-in-the-wall type of place, very clean with very attentive personnel. Try the pastor or chorizo. Steak is also great. You will never regret going here!

Their gorditas are HUGE, on size and flavor, great stuff! We tried their steak quesadillas, they were so yummy. Their gorditas were delicious, the place is a bit slow but that's because they make their gorditas, tortillas and sopes fresh to order

Who doesn't like a huge bean stuffed, steak topped quesamasatacorito? You might not find this off Clark spot. Seek it out. Decent vegetarian topping options too. They ask Red or green? I say Christmas!

I am so glad I found this place! I had been looking for flor de calabaza since my last trip to Mexico, and today I finally had a quesadilla with flor de calabaza and rajas. Not quite the same, but pretty damn close. Hubby ordered a gordita and a huarache, and we were both pleased with the fresh yumminess, handmade masa, and the flavorful sauces-- and that we got a box to bring leftovers home. The choice of aguas was great (and tasty!) and the prices are great, too.  If you are used to flour tortillas and endless baskets of chips, this might not be the place for you. But if you want to try something authentic, fresh, and delicious, visit this little dive!

Love the idea that the matriarchs are cooking behind the counter, no stacks of packaged tortillas here... had a Huaraches and it was great, fresh off the griddle with shrooms, pollo and poblano, very tasty, especially with their green sauce... There are only 5 tables, they do a lot of takeout, but service was great, too, with a smile. Will come back for more...

Everytime I come to this place its a big disappointment. The el pastore is horrible, everything takes forever to get your order and today I went at 11:15 which is 15 minutes past the time they open and no one would let me in. Although they had the blinds pulled down I could see someone cooking at the flat top and they wouldn't come to open the door, last time I ever go there.

Quality handmade quesadillas!  Love my half chicken tinga & half flor de calabaza quesadillas!  They're so big I always have leftovers, YUM!  Their salsas are also amazing.  If you dine in be prepared to wait in a tiny location but again food is worth it and the prices even better!
Love this place, a must when you are up north.Great food at a good price. Very friendly
they have great steak here, I like the burritos. They always give so many salsas too which is really nice
I live in the area and it is so hard to go anywhere else for traditional Mexican food.  It's legit! Love it!

Delicious, incredible, hand made Mexican food. Very glad this is in walking distance!  If they served margaritas it would be even better. :) love the huaraches, but anything on the menu is amazing. Plus the price is extremely reasonable!
so good , I mean everything is made fresh , form a scratch. I get hungry after work , and when I nearby I get lost of  food.  Its very fresh,

This place is very small so count on either needing to wait or getting carry out. The restrooms had no toilet paper and I had to walk through the alley (outside) and into a side kitchen door to get to it. I was charged for a side of rice that I never got but unfortunately didn't realize it until after I'd paid. The food was good but they charged us for hot sauce (aka salsa). While we were eating many different people came into the restaurant and walked behind the counter and we're just hanging out...probably why I found a hair in my food.
Stumbled upon this place and so glad I did! It's a hidden gem. Never had a huarache before but I will want more in the future. Super affordable also.
Tasty and you get  lot of food for the money!  Loved the huaraches.  They have a new loyal customer:)

Stumbled upon this place, what a find.  Authentic Mexican cuisine, delicious.  Ordered the Huaraches without knowing what was coming, a real treat. Just the right heat for this aging Gringo, fresh made corn tortilla, chicken, Queso cheese , cilantro and ????    I'll be back!

Nick is hilariously right about a few things for this place - all the way from 2010. It's not as underground as you'd expect, if you care about that. However, they are one of the few early places in Chicago to start making Huaraches, something that is far more common in Mexico than it is here. That also means that this is pretty authentic, and it shows. You won't see that many places that have done the fermented mushroom stuff either.  Food is fantastic, spices are excellent, but you'll definitely get a kick from a lot of the food. It's also a really small establishment, so there are only maybe 5 or 6 tables. As of from when this review was written to now, there are a number of places in the surrounding area that also make huaraches and this general style of central mexican cuisine. Just like how there are only a few places that make yucatan cuisine  It's an awesome place, even if you're stopping in once to get a huarache.  They do take card now unlike 2010.

The food is amazing, something I didn't expect at all. The guys over at Father and Son barbershop recommended this place. So glad I checked it out. Great service, cute outdoor area. Super satisfied. Will be back!
My friend introduced me o this place and i love it every single time. Quesadillas with corn mushroom and hot sauce.

I hyped myself all week for this place and let me tell you, I was not disappointed the second I left the establishment. Those huaraches will satisfy any being and whether you're a meat lover or a vegetarian, there's a certain style for you. Steak, spicy pork, chorizo + potatoes, nopales, mushrooms, chicken...this place knew your soft spot. I went for the mushroom huarache, with some salsa verde spread all over it, and was taken to Flavortown (shout out to Guy Fieri).   I've never been to this part of Chicago in my life, but thanks to the television show Chicago's Best (on WGN-Channel 9) they expose me to neat little gems such as Huaraches Doña Chio that satisfies my Mexican food cravings for when I'm in a mood that is beyond the usual taco, torta, or burrito deal. Come here for an amazing Huarache that is not only amazing, but is served by great rapid hard workers at an extremely reasonable price.

Ok. This place really sucked. First off  it took 5 minutes for us to get a menu.  Then, Eduardo had gone for chilaquiles, but they only serve those until 1pm. Whatever. We order our huaraches,  they are big. Mine had Carne asada and chicarron, which turned out to be shredded pork meat, eduardo had Carne asada and papas con corizo. Didn't really have much flavor. All you could taste was the oil they used to make the food. The waitress brought us rice and beans that belonged to the other table. Now mind you, there are only 6 tables, how the hell can you screw that up!  To top it all off, eduardo ended up throwing up on the way home. I don't know how this place can have an almost 5 star review from everyone else, but I would definitely give it half a star at the very most. Needless to say, the waitress didn't even deserve the $1.25 I left her for tip. VERY DISAPPOINTED! !
Great Mexican food! I especially like that you can customize your huarache!
Huaraches are amazing as is the chilaquiles. This place may be small but I never walk away disappointed.
Chicken tinga tacos made with lots of love. Excellent food at a great price.
This was an unexpected find, and the food was amazing. We got it to go, and the food traveled home well and was so delicious! I recommend the Horchata especially!
All I can is wow. Had a chicken huarache and wow talk about fresh. This taste homemade and delicious. Am def coming back.

This is the second time I ordered from this place... I must tell the food is pretty good. I did try so far Pozole soup, Menudo soup ... Those are soooo goood. The huaraches are huge and the gorditas also... Highly recommend!!!!
love their thinga huaraches. The restaurant itself is small but the food is so worth it. Would definitely recommend  this place :)

We (2 random gringos who were hungry and in the neighbourhood) wandered in here mostly because of the Yelp reviews. You Yelp reviewers did not mislead us. Not sure if it was Doña Chio herself who served us up 2 delicious slabs of the fresh, tasty, delicious, and shockingly inexpensive mexi-gasm known as Huarache, but mother of god I wanted to hug that sweet old lady and hand her the key to the city or something. It was like the entire nation of Mexico was high fiving my tastebuds. Recommendations: The Huaraches are HUGE. If you're average-portion eaters, like me and the fella, SPLIT ONE. Also, don't be a scroogy stingy penny pincher, woman up and get all three toppings. Chorizo was magnificent, rajas were even better than L'Patron (IF ANY L'PATRON EMPLOYEES ARE READING THIS, I STILL LOVE YOU) and the al pastor was probably the best I've had in the city-- perfectly simmered, perfectly seasoned prime pieces o' pork, not the third-rate gristly dumpster-meat you sometimes get. Man, I wish I lived closer. Anyway, keep making magic, Doña Chio.

OMG..... fresh Huaraches made from masa!!!!  Fresh masa tacos!!!!!!!  It just doesn't get any better than this if you like FRESH tortillas made right in front of you.  This place is TINY.  they only have 4 very small tables in a space that would do better with 2.  The food is super fresh.  It is sort of a dump........OK, it really is a dump in a basement, but the food is outrageous.  BYOB.

Ordered steak enchiladas with the green sauce. Got my order, took it home, opened it (I should've checked it before I left). There was no sauce on the enchiladas, the steak was on top, they didn't look like enchiladas, just 3 tortillas rolled with cheese on top and burnt steak on top of the tortillas....I've never had enchiladas that look like that. Maybe thats another way of making them, but I'm highly disappointed. I prefer my meat inside my enchiladas. Also, I got no salsa on the side. I'm not happy. Will not order from here again.

I've always seen this little place as I have walked around the neighborhood, but it wasn't until my husband heard about it from our barber that we decided to give it a whirl. We called in the order, and 15 minutes later I was walking up the block to get our food.  Yeah, it looks a little divey from the outside, but it's a homey mom and pop place inside: two women who looked about my mom's age were at the helm when I got there.  They make their corn tortillas on site, as I saw the mixture in the corner by the grill, which explains why they ask for at least 15 minutes. And they are completely worth the wait. I did chorizo and potato tacos, and two left me content and satiated. I love the onion /cilantro mix, but my husband does not, so his steak tacos only had cheese. The tomatillo verde sauce was a nice amount of heat when added on top.  A quick lunch for two, under $15 and a 5 minute walk from home. And they can even take credit cards. Win!
Good food here. Always consistent and always on point. The only thing that stinks sometimes is finding parking. This is place always has freshly made Huaraches!

This place is legit and super delicioso. I came here with family and left feeling totally at home with how the staff was. It's a total mom and pop restaurant with fresh and authentic cuisine. I got to check a food item to try off my bucket list: Huitlacoche. It was flavorful with a silky outside finish and creamy inside. I ordered that with my Huarache and also got their chicken tinga along with a horchata. Best horchata I've ever had, tasted milky and not overkill on the cinnamon. For dessert I tried the flan and that was a rather large slice (ended up splitting it with the sister) and it was pretty yummy, not amazing, but still very good. Can't wait to come back again!

Ay Mi Huaraches Doña Chio ----- Los extraño mucho!!!! Can't wait to get back home to Chicago.... This will be our first meal when we get home for sure. Whether it's Chilaquiles for breakfast, un taco for lunch, or un huarache for dinner....We love everything. Yes, sometimes you have a wait a tad longer than you would expect, but the place is small, everything is handmade, and fresh. Has the same feel as some of our favorite taquerias back in Mexico. Just an absolute fave of ours! :)
Keeping it simple:  Great homemade mexican food that is actually authentic and tastes homemade.  The best part, portions are more than enough and incredibly affordable.

They are selective when providing quality food to certain group of people. They can not like you and under serve you. Got great food when I was there with group of Latin friends, when I went by my self it was like going to place where I am not welcomed. Definitely NOT GOING BACK!!!!!!!

I heard about this place because the bf's hair stylist, a transplant from Mexico City, said Huaraches Dona Chio was his favorite Mexican place in Chicago. Neither of us had ever heard of a huarache, so we paid this hole-in-the-wall a visit. Turns out a huarache is basically a Mexican pizza, with a corn tortilla for the base, refried beans for the "sauce," and your choice of meat or vegetables, onions, cilantro, cheese, and red/green sauce as the toppings. We tried the pastor, (chicken) tinga, and chorizo. The pastor was bland, the chorizo was very flavorful, and the tinga was fine. The red sauce was spicier than green sauce. The huarache should be eaten relatively quickly because the tortilla gets soggy from the refried beans and or sauce and then falls apart. The prices are very cheap considering the amount of food you get.  We waited about 30 minutes for our food, and there were 3 orders in front of us. This restaurant is very small, maybe 10 seats, and doesn't have the greatest eat-in atmosphere, but it's a clean hole-in-the-wall establishment. In the future I would order take-out.

Go to Huaraches Dona Chio for some serious business. For under $8, you will receive a delicious gigantic huarache which literally folds over an entire dinner plate. My favorite is the huarache with two toppings, flor de cabaza (zucchini flowers) and al pastor (marinated pork). Now, the al pastor is a little different here and is more like a cross between tinga and al pastor, which results in a more stewy version. However, the sauce perfectly soaks into the masa. If you are not in the mood for a huarache, their tacos are also excellent in part because Dona Chio makes all of their tortillas by hand. And, who in their right mind does not love a hand made tortilla?

I ordered the salsa verde chicken enchiladas and I must say they were the best enchiladas I've had in a while definitely going back! lil hesitant in walkin in but went for it and glad I did. It is very small but very clean. Best random spot I've hit up by far.
Best Mexican food! Hands down! The staff and cooks are really nice. Highly recommend this place if you like tacos.

This place is sort of in a creepy part of the neighborhood.. Or at least, it was at night as the sister and I walked from the Raven Theater. Disappointed they close relatively early, but they were nice enough to let my sister and I order and eat in (when I placed the order, I assumed they'd wrap it up in takeaway since we were kind of close to closing time, but they brought it out and all). The food though. Hooo my god. Is amazing. Granted, we were starved and the food was scarfed down pretty quickly (just because they were nice and brought the food out didn't mean we were going to lounge around after they'd closed). The tortilla part of the huaraches tasted so /fresh/ and homemade and it was simply glorious. I just wish it wasn't so far away. Or maybe that's a blessing in disguise. Because I'd be frequenting this place like my grandmother owned it.

The best thing since sliced bread.  Not for groups larger than 4 and even then you are taking your chances.  I just reviewed Carnitas and Cookies in the same neighborhood...if you're deciding on Mexican food in Edgewater THIS is a no-brainer.

I'm fairly new to Chicago, and huaraches was not an item where I'm from, so I am a complete huaraches noob. This place is near me and has terrific reviews, so I thought it would be a good place to start. It's a hole in the wall type place, Spanish recommended, and the small staff was very friendly. It's cash only, be advised (a girl ordered to go while I was there - she had no cash, but they gave her the food anyways and she promised to come back later with cash). I ordered a 2 topping huaraches - paster and poblano peppers. The pastor was as flavorful and delicious as anything I've found at my favorite taquerias, and the poblanos were extremely tasty. The masa corn tortilla is homemade (of course) and the poblanos roasted in house (the smell was amazing). The sauces were so good, and everything about my huaraches was delightful - I loved every bite. This being my first experience with the dish, I could very well be a victim of ignorance, but I am excited to go back and to check some other places, as well. The only negative I have is that the horchata was not great.

I was at the park next to huraches doña chio when I smelled heaven. I had to find out what it was. I walked over and discovered there was a little hole in the wall Mexican restaurant nestled in a building on this unassuming side street. I wouldn't normally do this, but I had to order food then and there. I ended up going with the chicken enchilada verde as I didn't do much research and that's an old fave. I was not disappointed. The verde sauce was one of the best I've ever had. After talking with a worker there and searching reviews, I've since tried the huraches, which are their specialty. I tried the tinga and mushroom. Fantastic. It's super cheap as well and a lot of bang for your buck. Inside is not much to look at and there are only 4-5 small tables. But if you aren't looking for a high end dining experience, just excellent, inexpensive and authentic Mexican food, look no further.
They make their own tortillas The tacos are $3-$3.50 and SO worth it. I have not found weird stuff in my chicken. The huaraches are GIGANTIC.

I dunno why the heck I don't go here more often, since it's only a half mile away from where I live. But the tinga is really darn good here on the huarache! It's hidden off of Clark and on Elmdale, slightly east of the Clark/Peterson(Elmdale east of that intersection) intersection. Tiny storefront, but it's the last one you see before the alley, and directly west of a park. If you drive here, I'd recommend parking on one of the residential blocks slightly north of here, and walking back. The diagonal spaces just east of here and by the park are often totally filled up, for whatever reason.

Came here for lunch, the huracha was monstrous. The salsas and the tinga were ok, the cactus and the poblano were very good. The prices are very reasonable. It's a good place to go for a quick meal, but not necessarily worth going out of your way for.

We are pretty serious regulars here - we stop by most weekends and get an absolute feast, usually for under $25 including tip. We can usually find a seat, but there are only 4 or 5 small tables. The house-made mesa tortillas are amazing. Favorites are the huaraches (green or red chipotle sauce - again, house made and the red is usually a bit spicier), tacos, tostadas (I think these are on a more standard tortilla - not sure if they're made in-house; but they do usually come with lettuce, sour cream and avocado which is a nice thing to mix up with) and a rajas (roasted poblano pepper - again, they roast in-house). Favorite fillings are tinga (YUM), pastor, picadillo and asada. Burritos are okay, but nothing special - go for the huraches, tacos or quesadilla if you're looking for something special.
Had the pork tinga huaraches, which were spicy and obviously made with love. Highly recommended!

This is a little-known gem with delicious food at VERY reasonable prices. I would go again and again. I'd be there every day if it was closer to me. I had their tacos and tostadas, and both were fabulous. The dining area was no-frills, but the food there makes it worthwhile, and you don't have to wait long for your meal.

As soon as I walked into this place, I felt like I was taken south of the border. The horchatas, hibiscus drank, and other concoctions all seemed authentic enough to keep a solid base of people coming back and I thought that this place must be pretty amazing since it kinda is off the beaten path but it has a ton of reviews. I didn't know what a Huaracha was until coming here either, and they were interesting, but I am not sure they are worth all the rave.  That being said, its an authentic spot with some really great vibes and some unique options you probably won't find anywhere else.

This is totally a rinky-dink, no frills sorta restaurant but the food is solid. With a tasty half beef/half chicken huarache for less than $5, you can't go wrong. The restaurant seemed clean and the guy behind the counter was nice.

By far the best tacos I've had in Chicago! This is definitely not a trendy place, but the food will not disappoint. It's very small with only a few tables, and hard to find, but worth the effort. The staff are very friendly and you can tell a lot of love goes into the food.A real gem.
This review is going to be simple and direct. The huaraches are home made. The tortillas are made from scratch, and the chili sauce used is motherf$%^# great. Do yourself a favor and try it out.

This was my first time "Huaraches" experience.  The place was so small but packed, food is fresh and made from scratch.  Vegetarian Huaraches was good (both taste and portion size).  I would like to try other menu sometime in near future!

This was pretty good! I happened to get the veggie options this day. I was taking a little break from meat. My man got the steak. His tasted way better. Once you go meat, I guess you can't go back to being a vegetarian. I'll try the meat one next time. Overall, though, the service was great. It was a cute like "take out" type taco place with a few tables. Overall, good experience; we were happy.

Run...don't walk for your Huraches is what I was yelling while running to Huraches Dona Chio (I had to run there, literally, because they earlier the most other Mexican restaurants).  We had a Carne Asada Hurache.... What is a hurache you might ask? Well, let me tell you. That masa that apparently doesn't sit so well in my stomach, well, that's the tortilla and then a whole buncha other ingredients on top of it. It's like a HUGE Mexican pizza. The carne asada is delicious! The cheese is melty. The salsas are delicious. Honestly, it's a huge mess of Mexican deliciousnesses exploding in your mouth.  The  horchata  is DELICIOUS! Not too sweet...not too whatever else...just perfect!  I wish they stayed open later...or maybe I should start eating earlier. Either way, Huraches Dona Chio is great, the staff is SO nice, the food is pretty damn good, and the horchata is the 'ish.

A coworker of mine recommended this spot after learning that I live in The neighborhood. On a cold Saturday night after finding nothing in my fridge but white Zinfandel and milk, I decided to give doña chio a call. My plan was to order for pick up but hoping to save myself the 5 minute drive in Albany park traffic, I asked if they delivered. To my surprise they did. Yay!!! Probably less than 15 minute later the delivery man showed up(sounded like the man who answered my call). Very pleasant man he pointed out how chilly it had gotten and its not until this very moment that I realize that he must have walked to my apartment...I'm glad I tipped well :) So we ordered a "huarache de carne asada", "enchiladas de pollo con salsa verde" and "un liquido de chocolate". The huarache was HUGE, the steak was fatty and the flavor was just okay. What made the huarache decent was the mixture of the chipolte and green sauce. However, the steak was too fatty for us to attempt to finish. Now the enchiladas were a lot better; the green sauce once again the star of the dish. It was served with yellow rice and refried beans, the beans were well beans and the rice was better than average. The milkshake as my husband put it was "weak" and it "taste like nestle quick." Overall, I give doña chio 3 stars, the service a 5 and the food a 2. I'm tempted to try them again for I want to find a local gem, however, I think I should keep yelping for this isn't the one.

5 stars! Here's what you need to know: It's tiny.  It's easy to miss if you don't know what you're looking for. There are about 5 tables inside. It's cash only. It's FAN-FREAKING-TASTIC authentic Mexican food. And las senoras hand-make the tortillas. I just ate and now I'm hungry again talking about it. It's a hidden gem and you need to go now.

Not so impressed.  I had eaten from here once before and I thought it was better then.  My main issue is that they got my carry out order wrong.  They were not busy. there were two tables in use and they already had their food.  So it was just my order being prepped.  I knew I wanted nopales on my huarache, and I asked the waitress if there was something she suggested to go with the nopales. She said steak (in very clear English.)  I said great.  She then asked if I wanted everything on it.  I said sure.  So I get it home and it is the plain huarache with the beans (?), a very little bit of cheese, onions, and cilantro.  Of course I paid for the loaded one.  Oh well.  It tasted ok, after I added the salsa verde they put in the bag.  Nothing special.  I have other places down Clark street that deserve a look.

I just ate a carne asada taco on a freshly-made huarache and was heavenly! The place is small and they take their time, but the product is just amazing! A hidden gem on the north side of Chicago. Highly recommended!
The best mexican food in the City. Very consistent and cheap.

If you believe that Taco Bell is Mexican food you will hate this place, but if you want some hearty, homestyle Mexican food this is a hidden gem.  I love the huaraches and the quesadillas (which are made with fried masa patty from the huaraches instead of a tortilla). Service is slooooow. They make everything to order, so the slowness is understandable. Just be prepared to wait. If you plan on doing take out it's best to call ahead. There are a few tables if you want to eat there.

Recently, I was able to try this place, after a fail on another Friday night when they decided to close at 8pm (their sign and posting say that they are open until 9pm).  So yes, call ahead to confirm they're still open. The huarache I had was freshly prepared, and homemade yumminess.  I had half tinga and half peppers and cheese.  Both sides were delicious, though I think next time I would get chorizo and tinga.  That tinga was mmm mmm good.   I think the sauces could have been a little hotter, and I'm no spice fiend.  I asked the waitress which sauce was hotter and said, "Today?  I think the red one."  :)  I love it that the table sauces are freshly made!  But I'd say that they could go ahead and kick that heat level up one notch.  I'm surprised because I see that there are many reviews that talk about how hot the food is, and I had someone I know tell me that the food she had here was "face-melting hot".  Hmm.  So apparently the heat level of the sauces varies quite a bit day to day.

If you like authentic Mexican food you will love this place. Every thing is made by hand. If you ever been to Mexico and have experience a Fonda this is basically what it is. Every thing is made fresh every day. You can actually see them cooking every thing from behind the counter. Awesome it reminds me of home!!

I stopped by for lunch on Sunday.  The dining area was hot and tiny, with about six tables crammed into a small space.  There is a park nearby.  It looked like it had some benches, but I didn't see any picnic tables.  Still, if you're visiting any time near peak meal times, I'd recommend ordering your food to go. Most of the signs and the guests' conversations were in Spanish, which speaks to the cuisine's authenticity.  The waitress spoke perfect English, sparing me from needing to exercise my rusty Spanish skills. I ordered the Huitaloche (corn smut) Huarache.  I aim to eat vegetarian when I can, and the ingredients as presented seemed pretty close.  I can't vouch for the huarache masa itself, but it didn't taste particularly lardy.   The portion was large enough that I felt a bit over-full after eating it, so I'd recommend splitting it unless you're really hungry.  The ingredients tasted fresh and worked very well together.  I'm not fond of cilantro (it tastes a bit soapy to me), but it actually worked quite well in this dish.  I got the green salsa and was very pleased with my choice.  There were both red and green salsa bottles on the table, and I definitely preferred the green.

This is my favorite Mexican joint in the city, maybe anywhere. The homemade huaraches are just heavenly. Everything tastes fresh and healthy and isn't bogged down with a lot of unnecessary oil. I am a stickler for delicious food that's also good for my body, and I love that I can eat a massive huarache stuffed with all sorts of yummy ingredients and feel satisfied but not stuffed or food-comatose. I always get the same thing, because it just makes me so happy - the quesadillas! Made with huarache (instead of flour tortilla - this is great), meat, cheese, and I always add lettuce, tomato, mushrooms and onion. Their salsas are great, as well. The wait staff is super friendly, and on a few occasions I've seen family members and friends of the employees at their own tables, giving this location a feel-good neighborhood vibe. I do believe this place is family-owned and run, and it shows! Lots of heart goes into the making and serving of this amazing food, and I always feel comfortable and welcome there.  There are 5 tables, I believe, so be prepared for a small space. Great for a date!

This is probably the best, freshest mexican food I have eaten outside Mexico, and better than most I have eaten IN Mexico. Seriously. Fresh, made to order (from fresh-ground corn masa) tortillas, huaraches, sopes, etc. Fillings to die for, particularly the Barbacoa (goat stew), Asada, Tinga (spicy chicken), Flor de Calabeza (Sunflowers!). It's all good. All made by grandmothers. And all at terrific prices. Only a few tables, so nearly always crowded. Now stay away. I still want to be able to eat here.

Before coming in here, I had no idea what huaraches were. I just knew that it was a new (to me) ethnic food that looked delicious and that I needed to get in my belly. The name was promising as well. I like restaurants that imply they have a legion of old ladies in the back working it out and making food that's old school, crazy delicious, comforting, and that will stick to your ribs. I was the teensiest bit scurred, however, because my latest run-ins with donas in the Chicago area had not ended well. At all. I shouldn't have been worried because this dona, likely, chased the other donas out of town. Delicious. This is delicious food without pretense or markup. Come here because you're hungry and appreciate home-cooked food for days. Don't come here to be seen or pontificate on foolishness. This is real. Come here to be real. As others have mentioned, this looks like a refurb'ed garden apartment, complete with steps that go down and low(er) ceilings. There are only, about, 5 tables in the joint and the majority are two tops. This isn't a spot that's good for large groups. It is, however, good for folks who like to eat. And, because the food is so affordable, you can eat a lot. Not knowing what huaraches were prior to coming, I thought it a good idea to order two kinds. Luckily, my dining Girl Friday was up to the challenge. Purpley agua frescas in hand, we settled in for al pastor and chicken huaraches, one with red sauce and the other with green. Do this. Try both sauces but be aware that they also come in bottles if you need more than what comes with the dish. As for huaraches... do you like gigantic pizza shaped orders of masa loaded down with meat, veggies, spice, sauce, and cheese? Do you like knowing there's a real live dona in the house going to town on your food (rather than having one in name only)? Do you like varieties of agua served in Big Gulp-sized jugs? Do you like being able to eat like a king on a pauper's budget? Do you like supporting true mom & pop establishments? Do you like exploring your city? If the answer to any of these questions is si, get your booty to Edgewater and get ready to do it to it.

This is the second location (I believe) of the much loved huaraches spot that started in Edgewater. Their huaraches are stuffed with a thin layer of beans and griddle fried before being topped. There are two "sauces" you can choose from: red (tangy chipotle) or green (jalapeno tomatillo). The word huaraches means sandals, but these babies are much larger than any non-NBA player size foot.  I'm giving it four stars because of the diversity of vegetarian toppings choices (you can get two or three toppings on your huarache for ~$7). But Mr. W did not think the al pastor and tinga was as good as the versions he orders at another local taqueria (he gave it three stars but I'm the one with the Yelp account). I alos think it's a great value. I took half of mine home but Mr. W. managed to polish his off (and then slipped into a food coma an hour later). It's a cozy, bright and friendly spot along Lawrence. I'm not sure how it compares to the other huaraches place a few doors down, but it's worth a stop if you are nearby or looking for a good deal.

Hurray for Huaraches. Great food, freshly cooked. I love it and would recommend to everyone. Warning, small seating area.  Owners need to realize, you can't continue like this! Your food is too good and you will be overrun with customers soon.

Amazing is all I can say. Their hauraches are as authentic as you can get and they do them Mexico City style. I have also had their menudo  and it was out standing. It reminded me very much of the small stands in Mexico city that I used to go to. Also old Mexican ladies that remind me of my grandmother make the food.  In my opinion this is better than a lot of the over priced high end Mexican restaurants I have been too.

The huaraches are bigger than your head and the fillings smarter than what you got going on up there.  Don't be intimidated by the basement location and homemade signs en espanol.  You are welcome here!   The different prices on the menu represent different sizes of the huaraches.  The large size can fill up two people easily, and you can even split the pie if you want to try different fillings.  Try the tinga, it's delicious with salsa.

This is the kind of place that you would never find if you weren't just wandering around. It is the very definition of hole-in-the-wall. It says a lot about their food that people even manage to find it, and then go out of their way to come back. It's not near anything else to make it easily accessible. It. Is. Delicious. The food is ridiculously good, ridiculously cheap, and ridiculously large. All other Mexican food places bow before it.

Best kind of hole in the wall where you see tables overfilled with food and people just chowing down on all sorts of corn wrapped dishes and piping hot soup.  I had their huarache with chorizo.  The filling was as expected - good, but the kind of stuff you can get at any Mexican place.  But it was the corn masa, which was made from scratch right there that made it special.  They are huge and they're generous with the fillings.  For $6, it's a great value.   Parking is tricky in the neighborhood.  It might be easier to find something on Clark.

This was probably a basement apartment at one point - you have to step down a few stairs to get to it and it's in an otherwise residential building on an otherwise residential street.  You'll turn down the street not thinking you're going the right way, but you are, so don't worry! This is impossibly tasty food in impossibly huge portions for a fraction of what it should probably cost. Had we ordered one huarache al pastor (for two people), that would have been more than sufficient.  A masa cake that takes up a whole widescreen oval plate, covered in spicy pork, cheese, crema, onions, cilantro, and green sauce, it seems to swell the more of it you eat.  Just spicy enough to make your nose run without making your lips and tongue burn, it settles at a medium sizzle. But we knew not the massiveness of the portions before we ordered, so we also ordered the chilaquiles, which, despite my general dislike for steak, got me all filled up with tasty blackened but tender steak pieces, beans, soft tortilla chips, and that same spicy green sauce. As if that weren't enough, we had horchata and agua de mango to drink.  This is one of the only not-too-sweet horchatas in the area and I think they used champagne mangos in the agua! Bring a friend, feed the both of you for $5. (Quick tip for the small-bladder-havers like me: the sign says there is 'no baño publico' but if you ask, they'll let you use it.)

Fantastic little divey Mexican place in an off-beat location. Some of the best Mexican I have had anywhere - including Mexico... and if I understood it correctly, they get their mole sauce right from Mexico directly from some mole guru (probably some old lady in a tired little village who just knows exactly what mole is all about!) So great. Go here soon if you haven't already.

When I was around 9 or 10, I was enamoured with huaraches, a type of woven Mexican sandal that was hip in the late '60's/early 70's. My parents got me a pair in response to my pleadings, and they ripped up my tender girl feet. After that, I did not think or speak of huaraches until yesterday, when my love affair began anew. My brother and SIL found this little joint. Yesterday afternoon, feeling peckish from lack of food, the Greens picked up a six of Schlitz (taste the cheapness, 'cos it's BYOB!) and we all headed here. OMG. This is a palace for my cheap, broke ass. The food is unbelievably inexpensive and delicious. I had only $5 in my wallet, and that was enough for what I ate - or maybe I stuck my brother with the rest of the bill. Anyway . . . They serve huaraches here, which I had never thought about eating until this day. They look like a Mexican pizza, served on a giant corn tortilla. I am partial to flour tortillas myself, but these were delicious, so I happily consumed. I got the al Pastor - spicy pork, yum - with everything, and green sauce. YUM. This is the delicious Mexican food that I left behind in LA. Take that, overpriced Topolowhatever! A giant, pizza-looking affair that I was only able to finish about 1/3 of. As I write this, I'm noshing on same for breakfast, and I still haven't finished it all. That's 'cos I'm a damn petite flower, but still . . . it's a lot of food, for what . . . $6? The meat was delicious, juicy, well seasoned. Green sauce, cheese - and I smeared a little of our guac over the whole creation, between swigs of Schlitz. Mmmm! That's eatin'.  We were the only gringoes in the joint on this day, the rest of the people were families with kids. An adorable feisty little girl ran squealing with joy around the restaurant. Cuuuuuuuuute! We had a cute, friendly waitress, quick service in a spotlessly clean little storefront, tucked in a residential area of Edgewater. My broke ass will be back, living large on my frugal fashionista budget. Yum! That's how I like it!

Homemade corn tortillas like I haven't had since I left California.  Ask for the homemade cheese, which is very tasty.   Not much atmosphere, but we took our tacos to go and ate in the park next door.   Cash only.

Go, GO, GOOO!!!!  Stop at the ATM and head over to 1547 West Elmdale now!  Parking can be easily found on Clark. I don't understand why there are not lines out the door.  What an incredible little restaurant.  If my next visit is as good as this one, Huaraches Dona Chio will be my new and favorite Mexican go-to!  This five-table restaurant will blow you away.  There is nothing canned about this place. All homemade food - you can see and taste the love and care that goes into each dish. HDC offers the best in home-made Mexican.  All the tortillas are hand-made to order.  And, don't order too much - the portions will astound you.  I am a hearty eater, but it was all I could do to eat 1 gordita and 1 taco.  They use high-quality meat - we found no fat - and homemade sauces that will rock your world.  The tortillas are THICK - about 1/4 inch - and flavorful and could be an enjoyable meal on their own.

Huaraches = pronounced "wah-ra-ches" but you have to say it fast like it's all one syllable.  Got made fun of by the bf for over enunciating lol. We got the Huaraches de Tinga:  a huge homemade, thicker-than-normal tortilla with shredded pork in a chipotle sauce topped with onions, cilantro, cheese and green salsa.  I already had high expectations but it still blew me away by how good it was.   The super fresh tortilla was the star of the dish....it tasted like a mexican grandma had just spent the whole day making it just for you.  And lo and behold it was!  you can literally see the old woman behind the counter hard at work putting elbow grease into churning them out.  all of the toppings were great as well - the tinga was tender and juicy and the chipotle sauce/green salsa went perfectly with the rest of the dish.  i think they let you split toppings too so ill definitely have to ask for that next time and try some of their other meats.   My boyfriend and i split one huarache and we didnt even come close to finishing it so if you're looking for leftovers this is definitely the right dish to get.  All this along with a steak taco (super flavorful) and an horchata for around $11 (plus a nice tip for the old lady for working so goddarn hard even though we didn't eat in).   cheap, delicious and only two blocks from the house....ill definitely be back here soon !

Food+price was 5 stars, atmosphere was 1 star. Hardest thing is that there aren't enough tables and have to wait.  Is there any other Mexican restaurants make as good food as here with better atmosphere?! I am dying to know if exist..

Went to this place last week, Saturday afternoon for lunch. This place is pretty friggin' great. The food is definitely fantastically made, with low prices and large portions. I ordered the lengua huarches (as per the namesake of the restaurant) which was so big I couldn't even finish. Between two people the meal was about 15 dollars, including a cup of decent joe. The only problem I have with this place is the noise level--it's rather small, therefore very noisy when there are a lot of people--and the other patrons. While our waitress was a delight and very friendly, everyone else in the place was staring at us. Definitely awkward.
The huaraches are great, huge and delicious. I've been there a couple of times, the  service.is   ok.it  could be better if the restaurant was bigger, and the food took less time to be served.
Sum it like dis: byo, $11 for 2 to get stuffed and for me and my fiancé to iron out our wedding venue plans. Huarache carne asada and torta tinga tasty. We will be back.

Terrific! Far north side finally has some Mex worth bragging about! Been twice now and food was very consistent! Huaraches, sopes, gorditas, fresh ingredients, great salsa. The cocinera pounds out a fresh home made corn tortilla with each order (doesn't get any better). ~John C.

Pretty solid place. As someone else mentioned, the huaraches here were different than the ones I'd tried before. The ones here are still really good too. We tried a few things here. I think the highlights were the huarache with chorizo and potatoes and the quesadilla with squash blossoms. Definitely worth a try if you are tired of the endless places selling only tacos and burritos.

I've been duped!! I was totally expecting this place to be "underground" you know like this cool little Authentic Mexican joint that no one knows about. Then I see it has 33 reviews. I must find out a way to take out these 33 people so that only I know (insert evil laugh here)!! Then again, they also duped me into thinking I was going to have the meal of my life. It was good but I was a little disappointed. Those little shops are the only way to have authentic, hand-made, fresh Mexican food. The smaller the shop the better the food (j/k). To be honest, I've had much better. It's not that it wasn't authentic, hand-made, or fresh. It just lacked flavor. How is this possible?!? I started to think that there was something wrong with me, maybe I lost the taste buds in my tongue, so I went to my spice rack and dumped an assortment of spices in my mouth. Nope, it wasn't me. Everything was working properly as I chewed and chewed thinking that there had to have been a better way to test my theory. Maybe it was an "off" day, it is good enough and right down the street from me, so I think it deserves another chance (which I don't give too often). *** They just had their windows busted, so they are boarded up. They are still open so please don't pass them by. It's not their fault that there are shitty people in this world. *** Cash only

There's not too much parking on Elmdale.  You might have to park on Clark or Thorndale.  It's a couple of stores in from Clark on Elmdale and you have to take a few steps down into the restaurant.  There are only about 5 tables so there were some people ordering to go.   The main attraction are the huaraches.  The waitress spoke perfect English so it was easy to ask questions and choose which condiments and sides you wanted.  We had the huaraches al pastor and chorizo con papas.  Since I wanted everything on it, they filled the huarache with beans and then put it on the griddle.  The fillings were cooked on the side and combined with the cilantro, onions, and topped with cheese.  The portion is quite huge and it's $6 for one topping, $7 for 2, and $7.50 to put 3 toppings in one.  The al pastor was not as flavorful as I had expected.  The chorizo con papas was good, but for a Sunday, I felt like it could have used some eggs.  They have coke in a bottle and other soft drinks.  I would definitely come back to try the sopes and other fillings for the huaraches.  Because the place was a little small, it would probably be a place where I would go back for carryout.

I usually don't like basing my reviews on if a certain cuisine is 'authentic' or not. However, I'm going to make an exception in this case.  Huaraches Dona Chio is the text book example of authentic Mexican comfort food. Even down to the decor. The whole menu is in Spanish and the lady behind the counter speaks no English! But don't let this deter you, since good food is universal! I had the Huaraches Pollo. Made with very seasoned chicken, cilantro, onions and a delicious smokey sauce. I was in heaven! I would also suggest going there on the weekdays because it gets mighty packed on weekends with hungry patrons watching soccer...er um...I meant football! :)  Oh! The cherry on the sundae is the fact that they have REAL coca cola..ya know, the stuff made with SUGAR and not corn syrup. Yum! Stop on by, you wont regret it.

Now this is soul soothing Mexican Food! Around the corner on Clark Street is the new culinary showoff GaztroWagon, and it's tasty... if the GW is proving too lengthy of a wait, may I suggest Dona Chio?!?! It's just, really good. Big-Foot sized sandals of fresh masa griddled with your choice of preparations (Huilacoche (corn mushrooms)? Pastor? Heavenly...) Not overly spiced salsas and it's all just very tasty. BOTTLES of Mexican Coke (real sugar baby!) and you can get out of here for about $10 a person, no problem.

C and I came across this place, rather unexpectedly, while biking and returned last Monday night.  As unexpected as the discovery is the location.  It's on a side street and a few steps down from the sidewalk.  This adds to its charm.  It's a hole in the wall, but we like holes in the wall. Food:  1 star.  We really didn't know what to expect and never heard of huaraches before (sort of like a pizza; sort of . . . on a tortilla).  C had a plain one and I had one that was half tintga (chicken) and half pastor (pork).  Both huaraches were just delicious.  At so many Mexican restaurants I have been served port that has a great deal of fat; this had none. Atmosphere:  1/2 star:  Autentico. Service:  1/2 star:  For what it is, the service is perfectly okay.  The waitress had to hunt around for a wine opener, but eventually she did find one. BYOB:  1 star.  Yes, which we like. We're going back tonight.

After reading reviews I had high hopes for this place. Yes, the huaraches are huge. But I like my huaraches fried and crispy. These are just put on a hot griddle and served, more like an oversized tortilla filled with beans. It is filling, however you can tell that the quality of the meat is not very good. Originally it was a 3-star review but since the meat was such low quality in my opinion, -1 star. Probably won't be coming back here as there are many mexican joints I prefer.

I agree with the one reviewer who distinguishes between home-made and food that's done well. Yes, it is home made but I have made 2 different runs at this place about one year apart. Each time the food, huaraches or the tacos, sat in my stomach like a rock. The huarache was worse. At about 2 am, I thought I was gonna die. It wasn't good. The tacos de tinga were better but I still felt kinda' yucky afterwards. I eat at Xoco and Frontera with some regularity and although I wanted to like this place, I don't want to be tasting yesterday's lunch at 2 am. I won't return.

I'll repeat Morgan C - this place is a real gem.  Tiny neighborhood restaurant, you would miss it if you weren't looking for it (maybe even if you were?).  Has about 5 tables, when I picked up my carry-out it was packed with an after church crowd. The atmosphere is great for a hole-in-the-wall, and the food is amazing. Get the Huaraches of course!  I like the pork pastor.

The hubs went to pick up food from here...and we LOVED it. Everything was flavored amazingly. Seriously, the chicken is ridiculously delicious.  Here, you will get a nice taste of different Mexican flavors that you probably won't find at your local Mexican restaurant.  If you want to expose your taste buds to something different, try this place and you won't be disappointed.

Hello, neighborhood gem! Tucked away in a walk-down basement of an apartment building with seating for about 12, I would always see this place busy... and what's more, busy with Mexicans. Any time an ethnic restaurant is full of members of its ethnicity, it's always a good sign. Hurraches are made from scratch, or at least scooped and squished right in front of you. And they're delicious. Definitely more on the "guilty pleasure" end of the spectrum than "sensible eating," but hey... Burritos are huge and full of tasty fillings, not just lukewarm rice and lettuce like some places, even "authentic" Mexican places.  Prices are reasonable, though I wouldn't call them "cheap." But I'd rather spend the same amount of money I'd spend at someplace like Chipotle here.  The only thing I wasn't impressed with was the chips. Just your run of the mill, out-of-the-bag corn chips. Oh well, skip them and leave more room for burrito or a hurrache.

The type of meal where the whole time I was like "omfg" My first time there, went based on the other yelp reviews. I just had a gordita (it was simple and great), random time of day that I was hungry there was no one else but me and the owner sitting and eating and watching Univision. I'm not picky about the strict authenticity or ..Mexicanness.. or whatever people have been whining about, all I know is that the food was damn good and I have no complaints. I have yet to explore the other Mexican places in the area, I saw that there are tons in Rogers Park a few blocks up, so I'm sure some others are comparable, but whatever Also, because of its location I would never have found this, so thanks yelp.

I have been huarachefied! The place is unassuming, as is the service. I had the pastor, which was tasty and tender with the sweet tang of barbecue. I had a bite of the tinga, too, and it tasted fresh from the bird. The hurache's masa base was warm and fluffy, hand made by an abuela in the back. Topped off with an ice cold Mexican coke (made with sugar instead of corn syrup) and good company, it was a lovely meal.

I liked.  I didn't love.   Is it completely cliche that we ended up getting takeout from here on Cinco de Mayo?   We ordered a taco, a sope, a gordita and a tostada.  The meats were wrong on three out of the four.  Yes, we ordered the sesos, but on the gordita, not my tostada.  And the picadillo wasn't great, either. The saving grace was the huge and tasty taco.  I quite liked the carne asada and the red & green salsas were good, too.

Easily, the cheapest place I've eaten in 2009.  Defines "Hole-in-the-wall."  If you are looking for a wholly (hole-y?) satisfying meal for under $15 (for 2 people), you've hit a winner with this one.  My date (ok, my mom) and I split the Huaraches with Mexican sausage and potato...which EASILY feeds 2 people. Actually, it could stuff them. Like others have said, it's a form of "Mexican pizza," with cheese, sausage, potato, red sauce, salsa, cilantro, onion, etc. You can order it with whatever you'd like, and it comes on a sope like (but more crispy) "crust." FILLING. HOT. Awesome. $4.75. I kid you not.  All made in house, too.  Order an horchata for $1.25, and a Diet Coke for a buck...and wow. We even ordered a chicken sope (too dry for me) for good measure, and still the bill was $12.93. All together. With tax. Crazy! The service is uninspired, but that can be expected. If I was working for tips on stuff that was priced at $4, I'd be pretty unenthused too. However, our food all arrived, and she was adequate, just young...and ya know, not interested. The ambience is typical taqueria, but I recommend ordering "to go" and eating at the park next door... Credit cards ARE accepted.  You'd likely never find it unless you lived in this neighborhood, so here's a tip: Driving north on Clark past Ridge, turn RIGHT on Elmdale. It's a street where westbound is Peterson, and eastbound is a side street called...Elmdale. It's on that first block, on the right. (Elmdaleis a one way street going East). Parking on Clark may be easier (meters), but Elmdale has some street parking, no permits.  Bus: 22 Clark.  Or, ride your bike or walk. It's nice out. Then you can consume more huaraches. For cheap. YAY!

When I heard about this place, I got excited because it's in the hood and I'm always on the look out for new unique places!  We followed the suggestions of fellow yelpers and got two orders of Huraches. My husband got the Tinga (spicy chicken) and I got Rajas ( grilled poblano peppers with onion).  We also order a "milkshake" to split. Now perhaps there is a difference between what we think is a milkshake and what Mexico thinks is a milkshake. With that said, it was not a milkshake by our standards. What we got was chocolate milk. Which was tasty, but not exactly what we were expecting.  The huaraches were ginormous as promised and it was really nice to see everything being made right in front of you. When you put your order in they ask you what sauce you want and I asked for the least spicy of the bunch. That apparently is the green sauce. Which to me, a spicy light weight, was NOT mild nor medium. That bugger is HOT. And my husband got the red which is supposed to be hotter than the green. But he can handle that sort of thing better than I can. But he too said it was super hot. But he did finish his whole meal (within two days, it's impossible to eat one whole huarache in a sitting I think!) The toppings were plentiful and well spread out (which can be annoyingly absent on pizza, which this dish resembles.) and everything seemed fresh.  However, it was just too spicy for me. I couldn't taste much else besides the heat. So I don't know if there were other flavors at work or not.  While there seems to be lots of choices on their menu and some certainly unique, I just don't know if it's for me. I really want to like this place too! Maybe one more trip some time, the price is pretty cheap!

Found it amusing that this place was listed as "hot" among Yelp reviewers. Huh. The pizza analogies below (above?) are probably apt: the masas are gut-busting knife-and-forkers that will not freak out those familiar with the deep dish milieu. I'd start with the Tinga and work your way from there. There's a certain novelty to the huaraches the first time you come here, a novelty that sustains a 4-star review; yet I've been struck by the law of diminishing returns upon subsequent visits--it turns out they're just okay. Satisfying, sure, but only in a collective grease pit sort of way; nothing about the ingredients, their combination, the cooking method stands out. In no way is this place a substitute for Asadero or Carneceria Leon, my two pillars of Mexican street food.
Maybe I was there on a bad night but I was not impressed. Sure the place is quirky and everything is hand made but after eating my food I felt like I had a large rock in my stomach.

I am Mexican.  Was born in Mexico.  Most of my family is still in Mexico. Have eaten D.F. style food before as half of my family lives there--This is NOT it. There are places in this city that do serve it so it is not, in fact, unrealistic to expect authentic Mexican food from el DF. I read the reviews last night.  I got sooooo excited.  I live in andersonville and so far Mexican restaurant after  Mexican restaurant around here has been a disappointment.  So really the bar wasn't set so high for this place to begin with.  But since I was in the mood for handmade huaraches and tortillas, my boyfriend and I decided to give it a try.  So we walked up clark to elmdale to try it out.  I really wanted to like this place because I grew up on the southside of Chicago and so far the majority of  Mexican food on the northside pales in comparison to some of my favorite places on the southside.   That said, I'm not sure what most of these reviews are talking about but my conclusion is this: yelpers are confusing handmade food with quality food.  Yes, the tortillas and masa are hand made.  But no, the food is not good.  My boyfriend ordered a huarache al pastor and I ordered a sope with picadillo and a taco de carne asada.  He ordered an agua de jamaica and I ordered an agua de tamarindo.  Here is my assessment of the food.  The masa is not great, it's not bad but it's not very good.  You can go to a Mexican store and buy some premade masa that is much better than the stuff they make here.   Why I didn't just go do that and save myself the stomach ache after going to this place is beyond me. The quality of their meat is terrible.  They use meat with too much fat which they then proceed to over cook until it's so dry that the only thing keeping it semi-moist is the grease it was cooked in. And the quality of the meat in general is really bad.  I know this is a taqueria but there are taquerias in this city that would never serve that kind of meat. The picadillo on my sope was not picadillo--it's basically ground up beef that was cooked.  FYI--picadillo is ground beef that is marinated and cooked in a very yummy sauce made from tomatoes, onions, sometimes nuts, olives, etc.  This was just ground beef that was overcooked as far as I could tell. They ask you if you want your choice of meat accompanied with red or green salsa, except if the picadillo had been made properly it wouldn't have needed a salsa. (that was the first red flag) The carne asada in my taco was so overcooked that only the grease was saving it from being completely dry.   The huarache al pastor that my boyfriend ate didn't taste like al pastor--in part because it was smothered in the red salsa that they recommend you order.  Again, if the al pastor had been made properly, there would have been no need for that crappy salsa. Moving on to the salsa. The red salsa  that they encourage you to order on everything  is so spicy that you can't possibly taste any of the other flavors (maybe bad, maybe good--who knows!) underneath it all.  I like spicy salsa's but this one had no flavor other than spicy.  Good salsa's are not just spicy but they are supposed to be layered with flavors.   The aguas were nothing to write home about either but they were probably the best thing I had in that meal.  The only other redeeming quality in this meal (in my case not so redeeming) is that they give you a lot of food.  I did my best to eat this food because i don't like wasting food  but it made me sick and it made my boyfriend, who has an iron stomach, sick as well.  I feel bad for writing my paisanos a bad review but it infuriates me when yelpers write good reviews about food they clearly know nothing about.

Never knew this place even existed until I read Keshia C.'s review.  This place sounded so good that I decided to visit the next day.  Fiance and I dined in and decided on the steak and chorizo huarches (they ran out of chicken!).  We couldn't wait to eat because we were starving....but we waited and waited........and waited as we were getting lightheaded.  There was only this one lady preparing it behind the counter.  She was fulfilling a carry-out order and also had another table to cook for.  The huaraches are made from scratch and they were delicious.  I was surprised to find frijoles inside of the tortilla....not on top, but inside!  On top was a layer of green salsa, steak, cilantro, and onions.  The steak was juicy and well-marinated. One star off for the lonnnnng wait.  I don't think I'll dine in anymore, just do take-out!  Next time, I would love to try the spicy chicken.

What the f?! Why didn't anyone tell me where this place was before? Too bad its on a side street behind Senn H.S. where no one can see it from Clark St. Otherwise, I'm sure people will be lining up to go here. I've never had huaraches before, but I'm so glad I tried it. I ordered one with half Tinga (hella delicious spicy chicken) and half Carne Asada (since they ran out of tinga to make a whole one). Yummy! It's definitely best described as a Mexican pizza. It's made on a giant, handmade masa tortilla filled with re-fried beans, then topped with meat, cheese, onions, cilantro and your choice of sauce. (I had the red sauce, yum! No onions for me though, yuck!). It was SO good. (Personally, I preferred the tinga over the carne asada.) I was starving but only managed to eat half. The rest made great leftovers.  Stop in! The place is really cute, but gets kinda hot when the food is cooking. Expect a wait too because there's only one person cooking. If your in the hood and starving for a big meal on the cheap, go here. It's great.

Huge masas filled with refried beans and then topped with whatever Mexican meat/veggie combination you choose?  Yea, that's pretty much a huarache.  Something I had never even heard of before, and I'm glad we made the trip out here. Huarache Dona Chio is the definition of a hole in the wall on a totally unsuspecting little strip just north of Andersonville. We ordered our huaraches (for two toppings, i think $6.50 each - and easily two meals in one huarache) and waited as the owner prepared each one fresh, with telenovelas playing on a tv in the dining area. I ordered a huarache topped with tinga (marinated chicken) and rajas (sauteed poblanos and onions) and my date got one with asado (steak) and hongas (mushrooms). That is then topped with Mexican cheese and cilantro, onions, red and green salsas if you want. The tinga was deliciously marinated - not dry at all - but all white meat (amazing).  The peppers and onions were delicious and a nice compliment.   Food + atmosphere + price = amazing.

In the spectrum of traditional Mexican cuisine outside of Pilsen, Chicago falls quite short. However Huaraches Dona Chio is an amazing pearl in the oyster of the banality of Edgewater cuisine. Each Huaracha is made fresh in front of you behind the counter. For those not familiar a Huaracha is a corn tortilla stuffed with refried beans. It is then topped with your choice of meat and vegetable, cheese, cilantro and onion. The food is fresh. The ambiance is original and the pricing is perfect for this "Great Recession." This was the most authentic Mexican cuisine experience I have had in Chicago. For a Texas boy that is saying something.  Cash only, so bring your wallet and an empty stomach. You won't be disappointed.

Simply the best Mexican food I've ever had in Chicago. It's amazing. Even the rice and beans and sour cream are fresh and memorable.  Haven't tried the huaraches yet but I'll get those on my next visit. I can't believe I walked by this place without entering for a year!

Imagine pizza. Now Mexify it. And voila, now you have huaraches--delicious masa tortillas topped with fresh beans, delicious meats, queso fresca, cilantro, onion and the salsa of your choosing. Before visitng Huaraches Dona Chio, I'd never tried the dish before. So for my first visit, I ordered up the tinga and my dinner partner ordered the asado. The tinga was everything I look for in a chicken--all white meat, not too dry, and absolutely slathered in tasty, spicy chipotle sauce. Amazing! I ordered it with a green salsa, but I think in the future I'd hold off on it. It was almost too much sauce and the flavor of the green salsa conflicted with the tinga a bit. The asada was a bit fatty/chewy and just not what I imagine asada to be, so I may try one of their other offerings next time. The chorizo and the cactus both intrigued me, as did the huitlacoche, which is essentially corn mushroom. (Or if you want to get overly technical and perhaps kill your appetite, it's a fungus/disease that infects corn, but mm, mm tasty! apparently. Look it up at your own discretion.) As others said, the service may be kind of slow. (Kind of reminded me of Europe where you have to make it clear that you're done and want your check.) And don't be wary of this spot's basement storefront location. I'm looking forward to the summer when I can grab some tacos ($2.50 each!), huaraches and horchata (delicious!) and lounge about the nearby park and bask in sunshine and Mexican goodness.

We went for our first time last night.  Wow, that was a fun meal.  That was the first time I ever tried a huarache.  The red sauce was nice and spicy, which was a good thing. I can't imagine how spicy the green is.   You can't beat the price at this place, that's for sure.  They give a lot for the buck here.  My wife has a leftover meal coming up.  The bill for two huaraches and two drinks came out to about $15.  They were very helpful in explaining to me what a huarache is, and I was able to omit what I wanted (for me, that meant no beans or onions).   Also of note is that they have some pretty adventurous ingredients for the huarache, if one so chooses.  My wife added huitlacoche.  More daring ingredients include tongue and brains (not for me, but some do like this stuff).  I tried a little of the huitlacoche, and I think I will put it on mine the next time we go.  My wife remembered seeing Bobby Flay using it on Iron Chef once.  It's also called Mexican truffles or corn smut.

Started my new year's resolution to visit more local taquerias  last night, beginning with Huaraches Dona Chio.  That may have been a mistake, as I may not get to the others based on my delicious meal.  We ordered a tikka huarache and a 2-ingredient (they do this half and half) asada and pastor huarache.  In order, I probably preferred the tikka, pastor, then the asada.  The masa/bean dough based huarache itself was the star though.  It's especially fresh and delicious, and I loved the corn/beanyness of the tortilla.   They were a little overwhelmed when we got there, there are only 4 tables and a counter top, so it would probably be a great place for carry-out or slightly off hours. There was the stamp of approval "filled with Mexican families" authenticity barometer, as well as the "Uh oh I hope this place doesn't get TOO popular" barometer, as it filled up with people by the time we left.   Overall if I want quick and delicious tacos or delectable huaraches, I'll be back.
You Should: Make The Trip Sizzle: You have been eating crap Juice: Masa handmade by grandmas for tacos and namesake huaraches (a mexican pizza) that will blow your freaking mind Check Please: $
$6 for a huarache that will last at least 2 meals.  made from scratch in front of you, and just delicious!

I was a bit scared of this place when it opened because it's in a weird location on a residential street and looked kind of dive-y. But after the reviews on Yelp and in Time Out Chicago I decided to give it a go...and I am soooo glad that I did. Service is good here but not super fast, so don't start to freak out if they're not rushing around, the atmosphere is laid back. They only have a few very small tables - don't come here with a group or a fussy date, get your food to take out.  The tacos are an amazing deal with delicious fresh masa tortillas. Personal favorites are pastor and picadillo. The chicken tinga isn't bad, it's just not deliciously good like the pastor. However, it does seem to be all white meat - a big plus for me! I took a chance ordering picadillo (because I don't like it with raisins) but it turned out to be ground beef and potatoes in a nice rich sauce. I will definitely be back to try the huaraches (which looked awesome on other people's plates).  I really liked the handmade tortillas, and the tacos were a steal at $2.50 each! I'll definitely be back again.

This is seriously the BEST Mexican food in the City.  Like the other review states it looks like a normal taqueria, but man were we wrong!  The actual tortillas are made fresh and the tinga (aka Chicken with Chipotle spices) are phenomenal!!!  If you are in the area check it out!!!!!

This tiny little place just opened close by.  Don't let the street view fool you. It's your basic taqueria atmosphere inside, but the food is far from basic. This is a great little family operation with killer food.  Everything is home made.  Even the tortillas for the huaraches and quesadillas are made as you order them.  The food takes a couple of minutes more, but the extra wait is worth it.    They deliver as well.
